pages.title: Opposing Commanders
pages.description: In the late summer of 1808, the war between Sweden and the Russian Empire has turned grim for the Swedish forces in Finland. Russian armies have advanced steadily westward after crossing the eastern border earlier in the year, exploiting Sweden’s overstretched defenses and poor coordination. Swedish troops, composed largely of Finnish regiments, have been forced into repeated withdrawals—yielding territory, towns, and supply routes. After a difficult retreat from Vasa, the Swedish field army under Georg Carl von Döbeln has fallen back toward Nykarleby. This small coastal town becomes a temporary anchor point: close enough to the front to influence events, yet defensible enough to regroup, treat the wounded, and restore order. Here, with morale shaken but not broken, Döbeln prepares to halt the Russian advance. The confrontation at Jutas will determine whether the retreat continues—or finally ends.

panels.description: Georg Carl von Döbeln in the left foreground, black headband clearly visible, calm and authoritative. Opposite him in the right foreground stands the main Russian officer, rigid and formal in dark green uniform with red facings. Behind each commander, their respective armies wait in depth across open countryside under late-summer light.

pages.title: Nykarleby
pages.description: Calm before the battle, grounding the geography of the campaign.

panels.description: Panoramic view of Nykarleby: river bend, wooden town, and surrounding fields. Roads lead south toward Jutas; distant Swedish troops approach under calm late-summer skies.

pages.title: Retreat from Vasa
pages.description: The Swedish army withdraws under pressure, worn but intact.

panels.description: A long Swedish column trudges along a muddy road. Wagons creak and exhausted soldiers lean into their march.
Döbeln rides beside the column, silent and focused, rain-darkened ground beneath the hooves.
Exterior view of Döbeln’s house in Nykarleby. A modest wooden house under calm late-summer light, the yard quiet and still.
Interior of Döbeln’s quarters. Döbeln lies in bed, pale and weakened, head wound evident, soft daylight entering through a small window.
An aide stands over a table studying a hand-drawn military map, finger tracing roads and rivers.
Döbeln, still weakened, sits upright and issues orders over a map while aides stand close and listen attentively.

pages.title: March to Jutas
pages.description: Momentum returns as the army moves toward battle.

panels.description: The road toward Jutas opens ahead, river and fields visible in the distance.
Döbeln back on horseback, saluting as soldiers cheer and morale rises.

pages.title: First Shots
pages.description: The battle begins with skirmishing and advance.

panels.description: Swedish skirmishers fire from cover; first white smoke curls into the air.
Russian vanguard advances cautiously through fences and brush.

pages.title: Battle at Jutas
pages.description: The height of the fighting, chaos and simultaneity.

panels.description: Swedish infantry fires disciplined volleys through smoke.
Russian infantry presses forward, bayonets fixed amid drifting smoke.
Artillery fires with blast and recoil, earth and smoke erupting.
Döbeln on horseback directs the battle amid noise and confusion.

pages.title: Swedish Push
pages.description: The turning point of the battle.

panels.description: Döbeln rallies the line, sword raised.
Swedish infantry advances with bayonets, shouting as they push forward.

pages.title: Russian Withdrawal
pages.description: The Russian attack collapses and retreats.

panels.description: Russian ranks falter as officers struggle to hold formation.
Russian troops retreat into smoke and broken ground.

pages.title: Victory
pages.description: Soldiers salutes Döblen for the Victory

panels.description: Döbeln on his horse before the saluting soldiers

pages.title: Aftermath
pages.description: The cost of victory becomes clear.

panels.description: Döbeln walks among fallen soldiers in the fading light.
Field surgeons tend the wounded by low firelight.

pages.title: After the Victory
pages.description: The victory at Jutas halts the Russian advance in western Finland and marks a critical turning point in the campaign. Though limited in scale, the battle restores Swedish confidence after months of retreat and proves that disciplined leadership and terrain can overcome numerical disadvantage. The Russian forces withdraw from the area, allowing the Swedish army time to regroup and stabilize the front. Although the war will ultimately end in the loss of Finland, Jutas becomes a lasting symbol of resistance and resolve.

panels.description: A quiet battlefield after fighting: smoke dissipates over empty fields, abandoned equipment lies scattered, and distant troops withdraw into the landscape.

pages.title: Memory
pages.description: The past remembered in the present.

panels.description: Modern-day Jutas monument among birch trees. A teacher speaks to students; the same land now peaceful.
